message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Psoriasis has a genetic component and can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, similar to schizophrenia. Alport syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern, oculocutaneous albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, and familial hypercholesterolemia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with incomplete penetrance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Psoriasis is an autosomal dominant disease, which means there is a 50% chance of passing the condition to offspring. Schizophrenia is also an autosomal dominant disorder. Alport syndrome and familial hypercholesterolemia are both autosomal recessive disorders, while oculocutaneous albinism is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Alport syndrome, oculocutaneous albinism, and familial hypercholesterolemia are all inherited in a specific pattern, either X-linked recessive, autosomal recessive, or autosomal dominant.

Alport syndrome, oculocutaneous albinism, and familial hypercholesterolemia have clear-cut Mendelian inheritance patterns.

It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with incomplete penetrance, meaning that the chance of an affected father passing on the disorder to a child is 50%. Schizophrenia is also inherited in a complex, multifactorial manner with both genetic and environmental factors, and has an increased risk for offspring from affected parents. Alport syndrome, oculocutaneous albinism, and familial hypercholesterolemia all have known single-gene inheritance patterns that differ from psoriasis.
